WRITING.TITLE: I nearly lost my Pilot Metropolitan Classic Black today.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello.
My Metro is an awesome pen that wrote perfectly smooth, until this incident. I've had for about a month and a half.
I was using my Metro today when the nib started to feel less smooth. It kept on feeling less and less smooth until it stopped writing altogether. The Metro generally behaves that way when it has no ink so I check the cartridge: half full, which is unsurprising considering that I had changed it only a few hours before. I tried squeezing the cartridge to confirm that ink was flowing: it was.
I start to despair. I keep on trying to get the pen to write, and it starts to make little ink marks again. Very faint and sporadic marks, but still, it was writing. I guessed that the tines may have been spread apart, so I gently press down on the nib and draw little semi-circles on a piece of a paper, a technique recommended by jetpens. Between wiping ink off to check the nib, this, and the cartridge squeezing my palms start to look like I operate coal trains. But I'm so desperate that I can't care by now. It didn't work on either of my multiple trials.
The pen displays no symptoms of the other conditions on the website. Out of sheer desperation and frustration, I press the nib down on the paper. Hard. Surprisingly it works. I deduce that the pen had some rough edges, which wouldn't really make sense because I did nothing that would roughen the edges. So I try the figure 8 trick, still pressing hard. I try the pen afterwards, pressing lightly. The pen writes! Except that it wrote really large, like a Western B even though it is a Japanese M, and it stops after a few seconds of writing.
I'm practically on the verge of crying now(the pen is special to me), but I try to think up possible causes. I run a train of thought: the pen doesn't write normally, but when I release a lot of ink through, the ink flows unhindered. When I press hard, and spread the tines, the pen writes for a little before stopping. It wrote as if it was running out of ink. Therefore, something must have been blocking the ink flow. An obstruction wouldn't be able to block the entirety of a large ink flow, which would explain why the pen wrote when I pressed the tines apart.
I expectantly take my syringe, and use the needle to clean the ink channel; the pen actually works! The ink channel was dirty, or so I think. There's no actual reason why it would be dirty unless it was through normal use.
The pen means a lot to me, because it was my first "middle class" fountain pen (my first fountain pen is a cheaper pen, that works well, but that is outclassed by the Metro by far), and because it is a gift for my eighteenth birthday from my mom. It is the first pen I poured all my time and heart into choosing, and it is the pen that got me to use fountain pens whenever I could. It is my favourite pen, and it probably is the most beautiful pen I'll ever own. I actually would have given up on the pen because importing it here costs $40 extra, but by sheer unexpected luck, I got it locally for about $22. I'm really happy it's working right now.

WRITING.TITLE: Which ink is smoother?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello.
I'm trying to find an ink that could increase the smoothness of the writing. I've experienced with a few inks so far, and I'm looking into some other ink.
I tried Schneider black and Lamy black in the same pen (a Metro). Schneider was smooth in the pen. Lamy seemed to be less smooth, so I switched back to the Schneider, but the smoothness did not change. I kept on trying with Schneider, and I got the original smoothness back. However, I am not sure of whether I was wrongly angling my pen or misremembering the smoothness.
I also tried Quink washable blue and Lamy Black in a Vector. The Lamy Black seems to write more smoothly than the Quink, but the pen also stalls often for some reason. I do remember it occasionally doing it with the Quink, but I am not sure if my results are again the product of cognitive dissonance.
I also used Camlin Kokuyo black, Lamy Black and Schneider black in my Vanishing point. Lamy Black seems to be the smoothest, but it seems that the Schneider comes close.

Now, about trying to explain spiritual matters via materialism. I'd tend to disagree that there are things that cannot be investigated by experiment. One may posit that there is something that we cannot hear or see, but there has to be some way to interact with that something (which I'll call God for simplicity). If there is truly no way to interact with God, then does it matter if God exists or not? It's like Russel's teapot: if there is a teapot so small in outer space that no matter what happens, we will never ever detect it, does its existence matter?
By its undetectable virtue, its existence or non-existence cannot affect us in any way, otherwise we could detect it. But if we can detect it, then it must exist. I'm not saying that God is undetectable. Rather I am saying, that if God exists, then there must be a way to detect God's presence. However this does not necessarily imply that one can show God's existence without a doubt. For instance one might posit that the universe was created by God. It is pedantic, but the laws of thermodynamics are actually:
1. Energy is conserved. Therefore a change in the energy of a closed system is due entirely to the work done and the heat energy.
2. For any closed system, the entropy must increase, or remain the same. It cannot decrease.
3. It is impossible for a substance to reach absolute zero.
4. If two objects A and B have the same temperature, and a third object C has the same temperature as A, then B and C have the same temperature as well.
Out of the laws, the last two are not relevant to us. (I typed them out for the sake of completion. ) That objects tend to stay in motion or tend to stay at rest is actually the law of conservation of momentum, which only partially implies the first law of thermodynamics. More precisely, it is Newton's first law of motion. (I'm not trying to show off or anything, sorry if it comes off as such. I just like talking about physics.) In this case pedantry is necessary.
First of all, there is a problem with the concept of at rest universally. There cannot be such a thing: if one allows for Newton's first law, and allows for the laws of thermodynamics (specifically the first one), then there is no such thing as absolute motion.
That is, there is no way of objectively saying that an object moves; one can only specify whether they are moving relative to something else. Thus to posit that the universe is at rest or moving absolutely is to posit that either energy is not conserved and neither is momentum, which means that there is not much reason to posit a Prime Mover. Therefore, whether the universe moves or not does not matter.
One can furthermore show that the laws of physics had to be the same when the universe was around, if energy is conserved. If energy is conserved, then there is a theorem (Noether's theorem to be exact) stating that the laws of physics cannot change with time. Thus, they must have been the same for all eternity.
Either the universe has always existed, or it was created.
The eternity of the universe doesn't necessarily imply an infinite entropy. Entropy can either increase or remain the same. It can remain the same if there is no process happening. Entropy will increase as heat flows. If everything is at the same temperature, then no heat will flow. If the universe was in that condition, then it is possible that for an eternity, there was no increase in the entropy.
Then, one might ask, how did the universe reach this stage, because obviously entropy increases. One might suppose a really small universe. Then quantum effects could cause an inflation, which would trap heat in certain pockets and thus cause a temperature differential. This would be the big bang. (I'm doing a sloppy job explaining this. Sorry.) That's the hypothesis of Lawrence Krauss in his book A Universe from Nothing (I do not endorse or promote him in any way whatsoever. The book's scientific content is nonetheless interesting).
A multiverse is not necessarily unscientific. There can be ways of detecting the existence of it from this universe. For instance a leak in entropy, or a change in energy could imply that the laws of physics don't work, or that there is something apart from the universe. Of course, some versions of the multiverse propose that it is completely undetectable from here, in which case its existence becomes meaningless.
A universe that begun by itself violates energy conservation, thus sounds impossible. This is without contending with the idea that time and space begun with the big bang. Before that, there was no time and no space, and no time means that there were no unchanging laws of physics, and thus that energy need not be conserved. This allows for a spontaneous universe, and also allows for an infinite universe (without time, entropy cannot increase).
Of course, each of these explanations have about as much evidence as a Prime Mover. I've given a summary of why different causes are possible but I'm sure someone could find arguments for the Prime Mover as well. The reality of it is that we just don't know. The evidence we have points in all directions, and we need more evidence to confirm anything. I do not know if we will ever be able to establish a true cause, but not knowing whether we will have an answer is half the fun.
